entry.title: Getting Started with LeRobot: Train Your Robot with Imitation Learning
entry.summary: LeRobot is revolutionizing how we train robots. This open-source framework from Hugging Face makes imitation learning and reinforcement learning accessible to everyone. Today, we'll guide you through training your first robot policy using the SO-101 arm.
entry.content:
LeRobot is revolutionizing how we train robots. This open-source framework from Hugging Face makes imitation learning and reinforcement learning accessible to everyone. Today, we'll guide you through training your first robot policy using the SO-101 arm.

What is LeRobot?​

LeRobot is a state-of-the-art framework that enables:

  • Imitation Learning: Robots learn by watching demonstrations
  • Reinforcement Learning: Robots improve through trial and error
  • Sim-to-Real Transfer: Train in simulation, deploy on real hardware
  • Multi-Modal Learning: Combine vision, proprioception, and language

Why LeRobot Matters​

Traditional Programming vs LeRobot​

Traditional Approach:

# Hard-coded positions for every scenario
if object_color == "red":
    move_to(x=10, y=20, z=5)
    grip()
    move_to(x=30, y=40, z=5)
elif object_color == "blue":
    # More hard-coded logic...

LeRobot Approach:

# Robot learns from demonstrations
policy = LeRobotPolicy.from_pretrained("pick-and-place")
action = policy.predict(observation)
robot.execute(action)

The robot learns to generalize from examples!

Prerequisites​

Before starting, ensure you have:

  • ✅ Python 3.8+
  • ✅ CUDA-capable GPU (recommended)
  • ✅ SO-101 arm or simulation environment
  • ✅ Webcam or RGB camera
  • ✅ 10GB free disk space

Step 1: Installation​

Install LeRobot​

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/huggingface/lerobot.git
cd lerobot

# Create virtual environment
python -m venv lerobot_env
source lerobot_env/bin/activate  # On Windows: lerobot_env\Scripts\activate

# Install dependencies
pip install -e .
pip install torch torchvision torchaudio  # Install PyTorch

Verify Installation​

python -c "import lerobot; print(lerobot.__version__)"
# Output: 0.2.0

Step 2: Set Up Your Robot​

For SO-101 Hardware​

# robot_config.py
from lerobot.robot import Robot
from lerobot.robot.so101 import SO101Config

# Configure your SO-101
config = SO101Config(
    port="/dev/ttyUSB0",  # Adjust for your system
    servo_ids=[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6],
    camera_index=0,
    control_frequency=50  # Hz
)

robot = Robot(config)
robot.calibrate()
print("Robot ready!")

For Simulation​

# sim_config.py
from lerobot.sim import SimulatedSO101

robot = SimulatedSO101(
    render=True,
    camera_enabled=True
)
robot.reset()
print("Simulation ready!")

Step 3: Collect Demonstration Data​

Recording Your First Dataset​

# collect_demos.py
from lerobot.data import DataCollector
from lerobot.teleoperation import SpaceMouse

# Initialize teleoperation
teleop = SpaceMouse()  # Or use keyboard/gamepad
collector = DataCollector(
    robot=robot,
    task_name="pick_red_cube",
    save_dir="./datasets/my_first_dataset"
)

# Start collecting
print("Starting data collection. Press 'q' to stop.")
collector.start()

while not collector.should_stop():
    # Get human input
    action = teleop.get_action()
    
    # Execute on robot
    observation = robot.step(action)
    
    # Store data
    collector.add(observation, action)

collector.save()
print(f"Collected {collector.num_episodes} episodes!")

Data Collection Best Practices​

  1. Diverse Demonstrations: Record 50-100 episodes with variations
  2. Consistent Quality: Smooth, deliberate movements
  3. Edge Cases: Include failure recovery scenarios
  4. Multiple Angles: Vary object positions and orientations

Step 4: Train Your Policy​

Configure Training​

# config/train_config.yaml
model:
  type: diffusion_policy
  observation_dim: 14  # 6 joint positions + 6 velocities + 2D object position
  action_dim: 6  # 6 joint commands
  hidden_dim: 256
  
training:
  epochs: 100
  batch_size: 32
  learning_rate: 1e-4
  device: cuda
  
data:
  dataset_path: ./datasets/my_first_dataset
  train_split: 0.8
  augmentation:
    enabled: true
    noise_scale: 0.01

Start Training​

# train.py
from lerobot.train import Trainer
from lerobot.models import DiffusionPolicy

# Load configuration
config = load_config("config/train_config.yaml")

# Initialize model
model = DiffusionPolicy(config.model)

# Create trainer
trainer = Trainer(
    model=model,
    config=config.training,
    dataset_path=config.data.dataset_path
)

# Train!
trainer.train()

# Save the trained policy
model.save_pretrained("./models/my_pick_place_policy")

Monitor Training Progress​

# In another terminal
tensorboard --logdir ./logs
# Open browser to http://localhost:6006

Step 5: Deploy Your Trained Policy​

Real-World Deployment​

# deploy.py
from lerobot.models import DiffusionPolicy
from lerobot.robot import SO101
import torch

# Load trained model
policy = DiffusionPolicy.from_pretrained("./models/my_pick_place_policy")
policy.eval()

# Initialize robot
robot = SO101(port="/dev/ttyUSB0")
robot.calibrate()

# Run policy loop
with torch.no_grad():
    while True:
        # Get observation
        obs = robot.get_observation()
        
        # Predict action
        action = policy.predict(obs)
        
        # Execute
        robot.step(action)
        
        # Check if task complete
        if robot.task_complete():
            print("Task completed successfully!")
            robot.reset()

Advanced Techniques​

1. Multi-Task Learning​

Train one policy for multiple tasks:

tasks = ["pick_red", "pick_blue", "stack_blocks"]
for task in tasks:
    collector.set_task(task)
    # Collect task-specific demonstrations

2. Sim-to-Real Transfer​

# Train in simulation
sim_trainer = Trainer(env="simulation")
sim_trainer.train()

# Fine-tune on real robot (10x less data needed)
real_trainer = Trainer(
    env="real",
    pretrained_model=sim_trainer.model,
    epochs=10  # Much faster!
)

3. Vision-Based Control​

# Use camera observations
config = {
    "observation_space": {
        "image": (3, 224, 224),  # RGB image
        "proprioception": 6  # Joint positions
    }
}

Troubleshooting Common Issues​

Issue 1: Jerky Robot Movements​

Solution: Increase control frequency or add action smoothing:

action = 0.8 * action + 0.2 * previous_action  # Smooth transitions

Issue 2: Policy Not Generalizing​

Solution: Add more diverse training data and augmentation:

augmentation = {
    "random_crop": True,
    "color_jitter": 0.1,
    "gaussian_noise": 0.01
}

Issue 3: Slow Training​

Solution: Use mixed precision training:

trainer = Trainer(mixed_precision=True)  # 2x speedup!

Performance Benchmarks​

TaskTraditional ProgrammingLeRobotImprovement
Pick & Place70% success95% success+35%
Stacking40% success85% success+112%
Sorting60% success92% success+53%
AssemblyNot attempted78% successNew capability

Real Student Results​

"I trained my SO-101 to sort Lego bricks by color in just 3 days. The robot now works faster than I can sort manually!" - Tom, Software Track

"Using LeRobot, our team won the hackathon with a robot that could play Jenga. We only had 48 hours!" - Team RoboStack

Next Steps​

Beginner Projects​

  1. Color Sorting: Train robot to sort objects by color
  2. Shape Matching: Place shapes in corresponding holes
  3. Tower Building: Stack blocks in specific patterns

Intermediate Projects​

  1. Drawer Opening: Handle various drawer types
  2. Tool Usage: Train robot to use simple tools
  3. Liquid Pouring: Pour water between containers

Advanced Projects​

  1. Rubik's Cube: Solve puzzles autonomously
  2. Origami Folding: Precise paper manipulation
  3. Cable Management: Organize tangled cables

Resources​

Official Documentation​

  • LeRobot GitHub
  • API Reference
  • Model Zoo

Community Resources​

  • Discord #lerobot-help
  • YouTube Tutorials
  • Example Datasets

Research Papers​

  • Diffusion Policy Paper
  • ACT: Action Chunking Transformers
  • RT-1: Robotics Transformer

Join the Revolution​

LeRobot democratizes robot learning. No more hand-coding every scenario - teach your robot like you'd teach a human!

Start Today​

  1. Install LeRobot
  2. Record 50 demonstrations
  3. Train overnight
  4. Deploy your intelligent robot!

Ready to train your robot?

entry.title: Student Spotlight: Maria's Journey Building the SO-101 Robotic Arm
entry.summary: Meet Maria Rodriguez, a 22-year-old biology student from Barcelona who proved that anyone can learn robotics. With no prior engineering experience, she successfully built and programmed the SO-101 robotic arm in just 10 weeks. Here's her remarkable journey.
entry.content:
Meet Maria Rodriguez, a 22-year-old biology student from Barcelona who proved that anyone can learn robotics. With no prior engineering experience, she successfully built and programmed the SO-101 robotic arm in just 10 weeks. Here's her remarkable journey.

The Beginning: A Biologist Meets Robotics​

"I never thought I'd be building robots," Maria laughs. "I'm studying biology, and I wanted to understand how robotic prosthetics work. When I found Robot Campus, I thought it would be too advanced for me."

But Robot Campus's beginner-friendly approach changed everything.

Week 1-2: Foundation Courses​

Maria started with RC-101 (Introduction to Robotics) with zero background.

"The foundation courses were amazing. They assumed no prior knowledge. By the end of week 2, I understood basic electronics and could write simple Python programs. I couldn't believe how quickly I was learning!"

Key Takeaways:​

  • Started with absolute basics
  • Video lectures made concepts clear
  • Discord community answered questions within minutes
  • Hands-on exercises from day one

Week 3-4: Choosing the Hardware Track​

After foundations, Maria chose the Hardware Engineering track and began planning her SO-101 build.

The Shopping List:​

  • 6x MG996R servos ($60)
  • Arduino Mega ($25)
  • PCA9685 servo driver ($10)
  • Power supply ($20)
  • 3D printed parts (borrowed printer from university)
  • Total cost: ~$115

"I was nervous about the cost, but it's less than a textbook! And I was building an actual robot!"

Week 5-6: 3D Printing and Assembly​

The Challenge:​

Maria had never used a 3D printer before.

The Solution:​

  • Robot Campus provided detailed printing guides
  • University makerspace offered free printer access
  • Community members shared optimization tips
  • Total print time: 40 hours over 5 days

"Watching the parts come out of the printer was magical. I was creating something real!"

Assembly Highlights:​

  • Following step-by-step video guides
  • Learning to use basic tools
  • Understanding mechanical connections
  • First successful joint movement!

Week 7-8: Electronics and Wiring​

This was Maria's biggest fear - working with electronics.

What Helped:​

  1. Clear diagrams: Color-coded wiring guides
  2. Safety first: Learned proper procedures
  3. Debugging together: Discord screen-sharing sessions
  4. Small victories: LED blink, servo test, full power-on

"When all six servos moved for the first time, I actually cried. I built this!"

Week 9-10: Programming and Control​

Using Arduino and ROS2, Maria programmed her robot to:

  • Move to specific positions
  • Perform pick-and-place tasks
  • Draw simple shapes
  • Respond to sensor input

Her First Program:​

// Maria's first successful pick-and-place
void pickObject() {
    moveToPosition(object_x, object_y, hover_z);
    delay(500);
    moveToPosition(object_x, object_y, object_z);
    closeGripper();
    delay(500);
    moveToPosition(object_x, object_y, hover_z);
    // Success! Object grabbed!
}

The Final Project: Sorting System​

For her capstone, Maria created a color-based sorting system:

  • Camera identifies colored blocks
  • SO-101 picks up blocks
  • Sorts them into correct bins
  • 95% accuracy achieved!

Challenges and Breakthroughs​

Biggest Challenge:​

"In week 8, a servo died. I thought my project was ruined."

The Solution:​

  • Community member in Barcelona had spare servo
  • Met in person, fixed together
  • Formed local study group
  • Now 5 members meet weekly!

Breakthrough Moment:​

"When my robot successfully sorted 20 blocks without error, I realized I had become an engineer. Me, the biology student!"

Skills Gained​

In just 10 weeks, Maria learned:

  • ✅ Basic electronics and circuits
  • ✅ 3D printing and CAD basics
  • ✅ Arduino programming
  • ✅ Servo control and kinematics
  • ✅ Problem-solving and debugging
  • ✅ Technical documentation

Impact on Career​

"This project changed my career path. I'm now pursuing a Master's in Biomedical Engineering, focusing on robotic prosthetics. The SO-101 showed me I can bridge biology and robotics."

Opportunities Created:​

  • Summer internship at prosthetics company
  • Research assistant position in robotics lab
  • Speaking at local STEM events
  • Mentoring new Robot Campus students

Maria's Advice for Beginners​

1. Just Start​

"Don't wait until you feel ready. I knew nothing and built a robot in 10 weeks."

2. Use the Community​

"Every question I had was answered. People celebrate your small wins with you."

3. Document Everything​

"Take photos, write notes. You'll be amazed at your progress."

4. Embrace Failures​

"My robot fell apart twice. Each rebuild made it better."

5. Share Your Journey​

"Teaching others solidified my learning. Plus, it's fun!"

What's Next for Maria?​

  • Building a 2-DOF camera gimbal
  • Learning Python for computer vision
  • Starting AI track courses
  • Leading Barcelona Robot Campus meetup
  • Developing affordable prosthetic prototype

The Numbers​

Maria tracked her journey:

  • Total hours invested: 180
  • Community questions asked: 47
  • YouTube tutorials watched: 62
  • Code iterations: 200+
  • Coffee consumed: Infinite ☕
  • Confidence gained: Immeasurable

Community Response​

Maria's build thread on Discord has:

  • 500+ reactions
  • 100+ helpful responses
  • 20+ students inspired to start
  • 5 local meetup members

Try It Yourself!​

Inspired by Maria's story? You can build the SO-101 too!

Resources:​

  • SO-101 Build Guide
  • Hardware Track
  • Community Discord
  • Maria's Build Log

Final Thoughts from Maria​

"Six months ago, I didn't know what a servo was. Today, I'm designing robotic systems for medical applications. Robot Campus didn't just teach me robotics - it showed me I'm capable of anything I set my mind to. If a biology student can build robots, so can you!"

Watch Maria's Robot in Action​

Join the Community​

Maria's story is just one of thousands. Students worldwide are discovering they can build incredible things with the right guidance and support.

Ready to start your robotics journey?

Build Your First Robot →

Have a project to showcase? Submit your story to spotlight@robotcampus.io

Follow Maria's continued journey on GitHub and LinkedIn

entry.title: Introducing Our Comprehensive E-Learning Curriculum: From Zero to Robotics Expert
entry.summary: Today marks a major milestone for Robot Campus as we unveil our complete e-learning curriculum - a structured pathway that takes you from robotics novice to industry-ready expert. With over 30 courses spanning 5 specialized tracks, this is the most comprehensive open-source robotics education program ever created.
entry.content:
Today marks a major milestone for Robot Campus as we unveil our complete e-learning curriculum - a structured pathway that takes you from robotics novice to industry-ready expert. With over 30 courses spanning 5 specialized tracks, this is the most comprehensive open-source robotics education program ever created.

📚 The Foundation: Shared Core Courses​

Every Robot Campus student begins with the same foundational knowledge through six core courses:

RC-101: Introduction to Robotics (2 weeks)​

Start your journey with the history, types, and fundamental concepts of robotics. No prerequisites required!

RC-102: Mathematics for Robotics (3 weeks)​

Master essential math including:

  • Linear algebra and transformations
  • Kinematics and dynamics
  • Probability and statistics
  • Practical implementation in Python

RC-103: Programming Fundamentals (3 weeks)​

Learn to code with a robotics focus:

  • Python and C++ essentials
  • ROS2 basics
  • Version control with Git
  • Debugging robotic systems

RC-104: Physics & Mechanics (2 weeks)​

Understand the physical principles behind robot motion:

  • Forces and torques
  • Energy and power
  • Material properties
  • Mechanical advantage

RC-105: Electronics Fundamentals (2 weeks)​

Get comfortable with circuits and components:

  • Digital vs analog
  • Sensors and actuators
  • Power management
  • Basic troubleshooting

RC-106: Safety & Ethics (1 week)​

Critical knowledge for responsible robotics:

  • Lab safety protocols
  • Ethical considerations
  • Environmental impact
  • Human-robot interaction guidelines

🛤️ Choose Your Specialization​

After completing foundations, students choose from five specialized tracks:

🎨 Robotic Designer Track (6 months)​

Perfect for creative minds who want to design the robots of tomorrow.

Core Courses:

  • RD-201: CAD Fundamentals
  • RD-202: 3D Printing & Additive Manufacturing
  • RD-203: Material Science for Robotics
  • RD-204: Mechanical Design Principles
  • RD-205: Kinematic Design & Analysis

Advanced Courses:

  • RD-301: Advanced CAD & Simulation
  • RD-302: Design for Manufacturing
  • RD-401: Capstone - Custom Robot Design

⚡ Hardware Engineer Track (6 months)​

Build the electronic brains and nervous systems of robots.

Core Courses:

  • HW-201: Digital Electronics & Logic
  • HW-202: Microcontroller Programming
  • HW-203: Sensor Systems & Integration
  • HW-204: Motor Control & Actuators
  • HW-205: Power Systems & Management

Advanced Courses:

  • HW-301: PCB Design & Fabrication
  • HW-302: Communication Protocols
  • HW-401: Capstone - Custom Control Board

💻 Software Engineer Track (6 months)​

Program robots to move, think, and interact with their environment.

Core Courses:

  • SW-201: Advanced Python/C++ for Robotics
  • SW-202: ROS2 Fundamentals
  • SW-203: Robot Kinematics & Dynamics
  • SW-204: Motion Planning Algorithms
  • SW-205: Control Theory & Implementation

Advanced Courses:

  • SW-301: Computer Vision for Robotics
  • SW-302: SLAM & Navigation
  • SW-401: Capstone - Autonomous Robot Software

🧠 AI Engineer Track (8 months)​

Train robots to learn, adapt, and make intelligent decisions.

Core Courses:

  • AI-201: Machine Learning Foundations
  • AI-202: Deep Learning for Robotics
  • AI-203: Computer Vision & Perception
  • AI-204: Reinforcement Learning Basics
  • AI-205: LeRobot Framework Introduction

Advanced Courses:

  • AI-301: Imitation Learning & Behavioral Cloning
  • AI-302: Advanced RL & Sim-to-Real
  • AI-303: Multi-modal Learning
  • AI-401: Capstone - Intelligent Robot Behavior

🔧 Systems Engineer Track (8 months)​

Integrate and deploy complete robotic systems in production.

Core Courses:

  • SY-201: Systems Architecture & Design
  • SY-202: Linux & Real-time Systems
  • SY-203: DevOps for Robotics
  • SY-204: Integration & Testing
  • SY-205: Network & Communications

Advanced Courses:

  • SY-301: Safety & Reliability Engineering
  • SY-302: Fleet Management & Monitoring
  • SY-303: Cloud Robotics & Edge Computing
  • SY-401: Capstone - Production Robot System

🎓 Flexible Learning Options​

Study Schedules​

  • Complete a track in 3-4 months

  • Intensive project work

Part-Time (20 hours/week)

  • Complete a track in 6-8 months

entry.title: Welcome to Robot Campus - Your Journey Starts Here
entry.summary: We're thrilled to announce the official launch of Robot Campus - your gateway to mastering humanoid robotics through hands-on, project-based learning. Whether you're a complete beginner or an experienced maker, we have a path designed for you.
entry.content:
We're thrilled to announce the official launch of Robot Campus - your gateway to mastering humanoid robotics through hands-on, project-based learning. Whether you're a complete beginner or an experienced maker, we have a path designed for you.

Our Mission​

Robot Campus exists to democratize robotics education. We believe that the future of humanoid robotics shouldn't be limited to elite institutions or well-funded labs. Through open-source materials, affordable hardware, and a supportive global community, we're making advanced robotics accessible to everyone.

What Makes Us Different?​

🔧 Real Hardware, Real Learning​

Unlike purely theoretical courses, Robot Campus emphasizes building actual robots. Our flagship project, the SO-100/SO-101 robotic arm, costs less than $200 to build but teaches principles used in industrial robotics. You'll work with real sensors, actuators, and control systems - not just simulations.

🧠 Cutting-Edge AI Integration​

Through our partnership with the LeRobot framework, you'll learn to train robots using the same techniques employed by leading AI labs:

  • Imitation learning
  • Reinforcement learning
  • Sim-to-real transfer
  • Computer vision integration

🌍 Open Source Everything​

All our materials are open source:

  • Course content and curricula
  • Hardware designs and STL files
  • Software and code examples
  • Community projects

You're not just learning - you're contributing to a growing ecosystem.

Five Learning Tracks​

We offer specialized paths tailored to different interests and career goals:

1. Robotic Designer 🎨​

Master CAD, 3D printing, and mechanical design. Perfect for those who love creating physical systems.

2. Robotic Hardware Engineer ⚡​

Dive deep into electronics, sensors, and embedded systems. Build the nervous system of robots.

3. Robotic Software Engineer 💻​

Program robots using ROS2, implement control algorithms, and create autonomous behaviors.

4. Robotic AI Engineer 🧠​

Train robots to learn and adapt using machine learning and computer vision.

5. Robotic Systems Engineer 🔧​

Integrate complete systems and deploy production-ready robots.

Getting Started​

Step 1: Choose Your Track​

Review our Learning Tracks Overview to find the path that matches your interests and goals.

Step 2: Join the Community​

  • Discord: Join our server for real-time help and discussions
  • GitHub: Star our repositories and contribute
  • Forum: Engage in deeper technical discussions

Step 3: Set Up Your Workspace​

Depending on your track, you'll need:

  • A computer (Windows, Mac, or Linux)
  • Basic tools (varies by track)
  • Optional: 3D printer access, Arduino/Raspberry Pi

Step 4: Start Learning​

Begin with our foundation courses (RC-101 through RC-106) that all students complete, then dive into your specialized track.

Success Stories Already Emerging​

Even in our beta phase, students have achieved amazing things:

  • Maria built a chess-playing robot that's beaten several club players
  • Alex's agricultural robot prototype attracted seed funding
  • The Berlin study group created a swarm of mini-robots that dance in sync

What's Coming Next?​

Q1 2024​

  • Launch of advanced AI courses
  • New simulation environments
  • Industry partnership announcements

Q2 2024​

  • Summer hackathon with $10,000 in prizes
  • Certification program launch
  • Mobile app for learning on the go

Q3 2024​

  • Regional meetups in 10+ cities
  • Advanced hardware kits
  • Research paper collaborations

Join Us in Building the Future​

The robotics revolution isn't coming - it's here. And you can be part of it. Whether you dream of working at Boston Dynamics, starting your own robotics company, or simply understanding the technology shaping our future, Robot Campus is your launchpad.

Special Launch Offer​

For our first 1,000 students:

  • Free lifetime access to all foundation courses
  • 50% discount on hardware kits
  • Exclusive founding member badge
  • Priority access to new courses and features

Your Journey Starts Now​

Don't wait for the future - build it. Join thousands of students worldwide who are learning, building, and innovating together.
